thread.title: Brexit bill must not be obstructed, Theresa May tells MPs
thread.title_full: Brexit bill must not be obstructed, Theresa May tells MPs

author: Rowena Mason Deputy political editor
title: Brexit bill must not be obstructed, Theresa May tells MPs
text:
EU referendum and Brexit Brexit bill must not be obstructed, Theresa May tells MPs 
PM warns against delaying tactics as bill enters second phase of parliamentary debate with dozens of amendments tabled The Brexit article 50 bill, introduced by the government to seek parliamentary approval to start the process of leaving the European Union. Photograph: Toby Melville/Reuters   Rowena Mason Deputy political editor   17.00   17.02 GMT 
Theresa May has warned MPs not to obstruct the Brexit bill during its second phase of parliamentary debate, after the House of Commons voted overwhelmingly for the legislation last week. 
The prime minister said MPs must not use parliamentary procedures to delay the passage of the bill, which will be debated over the next three days. 
Dozens of amendments have been tabled by opposition MPs in the hope of getting enough cross-party support to secure better parliamentary scrutiny of Brexit, the rights of EU nationals living in the UK, access to the single market and a more meaningful vote at the end of the two-year negotiations. 
May appears to be standing firm on these issues, although No 10 could have to make concessions if enough Tory backbenchers look set to rebel. 
“Our European partners now want to get on with the negotiations, so do I, and so does this House, which last week voted by a majority of 384 in support of the government triggering article 50,” she said. 
“There are of course further stages for the bill in committee and in the Lords and it is right that this process should be completed properly. The Guardian view on the Brexit white paper: encouraging delusions | Editorial Read more 
“But the message is clear to all – this House has spoken and now is not the time to obstruct the democratically expressed wishes of the British people. 
“It is time to get on with leaving the European Union and building an independent, self-governing, global Britain.” 
She made the remarks while giving a statement to the House of Commons on last week’s informal summit in Malta. 
May was pressed several times to guarantee the rights of EU nationals living in the UK, with Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn saying it was a matter of human rights and decency. 
The prime minister insisted it would be a matter for early agreement during the negotiations with the EU and she was confident of a deal, while claiming it was “not the right way forward” to make a unilateral declaration. 
“As I have said before, EU citizens living in the UK make a vital contribution to our economy and our society and without them we would be poorer and our public services weaker,” she said. 
“So we will make securing the reciprocal agreement that will guarantee their status a priority as soon as the negotiations begin, and I want to see this agreed as soon as possible because that is in everyone’s interests.”
